EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 
Mammoth Pacific staff are not First Responders. Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency.  Mammoth Pacific coordinates with the local fire department through activities such as conducting plant tours, inviting fire fighters to annual emergency response drills, providing current emergency response documents and supporting responders with annual donations.  Site visits have been coordinated the last several years and another visit is scheduled prior to the commissioning of CD4.
An emergency action plan is in place that meets the requirements of CalARP, EPA RMP, OSHA PSM and CalOSHA PSM.

Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, 2745.7(q); the following external events analysis information were reviewed and are submitted with the CalARP documentation: 
?	The types of natural and human caused external events considered in the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) Section 2760.2. 
o	During the May 2019 PHA , the PHA team considered a broad list of external events. The PHA addressed general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of motive fluid. The External Events that were considered are detailed within the PHA worksheets, which are included in the CalARP document.
?	In June 2019, Mammoth Pacific performed a seismic assessment of piping and equipment for the existing G1, G2 and G3 plants.  Although CD4 is newly constructed, a seismic assessment will be conducted after construction is completed.

Design safeguards include the following: 
?	Automatic Shutdown is initiated when select process variable ranges are exceeded.
o	Stop brine flow, initiating unit depressurization
o	Close process isolation valves, removing motive fluid feed to turbines to stop turbine rotation
o	Stop process feed pumps
o	Disconnect electrical grid breakers 
?	Operator-initiated Shutdown can be activated from the control room and from various locations around the stationary source to prompt the same actions initiated by an automatic shutdown. 
?	Pressure Relief System is designed to prevent system overpressure due to process upsets such as blocked flow or accidents resulting in equipment exposure to fire.
?	Perimeter Deluge System 
?	Physical Separation of Processes from all but a few potential public receptors.
Safety programs are defined by the Accidental Release Prevention Program described below.
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
As part of the implementation of the accidental release prevention programs, program elements are documented and implemented by Mammoth Pacific to manage process safety issues associated with the use of the motive fluids. In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently followed to ensure safe practices are being performed.
The facility's `maximum intended inventory of the motive fluids is over the 10,000 pound regulatory threshold quantity in each process. As a result, each of the covered processes is subject to CalARP Program Level 3, EPA RMP Program Level 3, Cal/OSHA PSM and Federal OSHA PSM.
The Prevention Program 3 elements include:

?	Mechanical Integrity

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
No accident has occurred at the Mammoth Pac

s operations.
The CD4 process utilizes normal butane and isopentane as motive fluids.  With the construction of the new CD4 process, Mammoth Pacific is updating the Federal RMP and CalARP documents in anticipation of  the 2022 process commissioning. 
The regulated substances managed at the stationary source are the previously-mentioned motive fluids, isobutane, normal butane and isopentane. The motive fluid circulates in a closed-loop power cycle, traveling through accumulators, pumps, heat exchangers, turbines, and condensers to produce electricity with turbine-driven generators. The electricity generated by this process is then sold to contracted off-takers. The maximum intended inventory is 684,604 pounds of isobutane, 576,088 pounds of normal butane and 280,811 pounds of isopentane.  
The site is currently operated by Mammoth Pacific staff and is manned 24 hours a day. The facility employs approximately 24 personnel.
HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: One worst-case analysis has been defined and modeled for each of the three geothermal power processes. The results are included with the CalARP submittal. 
Alternate Release Scenarios Results Summary
Scenario Description: An alternate release scenario was modeled for each of the three geothermal power processes. The results are included with the CalARP submittal.
Release Scenario Depiction
The worst case and alternate release scenario document include a pictorial depiction of the potential release impact zones.  This document is included in the RMP submittal and is also attached as a file to the EPA RMP eSubmit document.

At the time of the G1 retrofit, Mammoth Pacific updated the EPA RMP and CalARP documentation to reflect the revised system.  
The G2 and G3 plants were built in 1990.  Given their relative proximity, they comprise a single process.  Both G2 and G3 utilize isobutane as the motive fluid.  
In 2016, Mammoth Pacific replaced the G2 air-cooled condensers with new units.
In 2016, Mammoth Pacific replaced two of the six heat exchangers at G3 with new units.
In mid-2019, Mammoth Pacific retrofitted the G3 plant with new, more efficient equipment.  As part of this program, Mammoth Pacific:
?	Replaced all turbines, turbine seals and lubrication systems with new equipment
?	Replaced all but two PSVs in the motive fluid and brine systems.  Those will be replaced in 2022.
?	Installed new instrumentation and a new control system
?	Replaced large piping segments involved in previous release incidents

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES
The Mammoth Pacific facility uses geothermal resources to generate carbon-free baseline power, consistent with and supporting California's climate goals.  
Mammoth Pacific has developed a risk management program and an emergency response plan to address California Accidental Release Prevention Program requirements (CalARP - California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, §2735-2785), the EPA Risk Management Program (EPA RMP - 40CFR68), OSHA Process Safety Management (OSHA PSM - 29CFR1910.119) and Cal/OSHA Process Safety Management (CalOSHA PSM - California Code of Regulations, Title 8, §5189). Mammoth Pacific has and will continue to work in collaboration with the CUPA in the development and implementation of this risk management program, including further revisions as appropriate. . 
Mammoth Pacific has a long-standing and strong commitment to worker and public safety and the safety of the neighboring community. This commitment is demonstrated by, among other things, the resources invested in accident prevention, personnel training, multifaceted inspection programs, and the priority placed on safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the motive fluid systems. Mammoth Pacific staff is highly trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using those motive fluids for geothermal power production.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
Mammoth Pacific's geothermal power production facility is fueled by geothermal brine from the Casa Diablo Geothermal Reservoir. The facility is located in Mammoth Lakes, California, approximately 5 miles east of the Town of Mammoth Lakes and 0.5 miles east of State Route 395.  The area around the facility is rugged and generally uninhabited. The facility uses the process motive fluids as working fluids in a binary Rankine cycle process for power production.
